review_title: Supportive team and lots of opportunities to apply & develop skills!
job_title: Therapy Team Manager and Complex Case Therapist in London, England
pros: UP is very welcoming and supportive, with lots of opportunities to use and develop therapeutic and management skills.  UP's systems are very efficient and there are excellent resources available to support planning.   Hub Managers are accessible and thoughtful and I appreciate our regular team meetings and training. UP's Safeguarding policies and procedures are robust and give me confidence in keeping the children we work with safe. Perks include clinical supervision costs being covered by UP and you can book relevant CPD trainings within work hours.
cons:
Time off in school holidays is a great bonus, however, this does mean the salary is pro-rata-ed down as a result. 
At times being the only therapist on-site at school can feel lonely, so it's important to make use of the opportunities to link in with the rest of the team.

pros: It’s lovely to work for an organisation that is really making a difference. The results speak for themselves. This charity is able to reach vulnerable children who are slipping through the net and is improving the children’s day to day experiences and life chances. The staff at Unlocking Potential are some of the most passionate, creative and determined people I have ever worked with. This means that the team tends to be very supportive of each other and makes it a great place to work.
cons: As you would expect, a small charity can’t match the benefits and salaries of large organisations, like the NHS and big corporates. However, they still prioritise staff’s mental health support staff with their CPD . We have access to the BUPA helpline, team building days, training for CPD and the charity closes for a fees days over Christmas which encourages staff to rest.

review_title: Hard work is not reflected in salary
pros:
Unlocking Potential is a growing charity that supports many children in need.
Dedicated team of colleagues.
cons:
Hard work in schools across London.
The salaries are okay for newly qualified staff needing to gain some experience. However, salaries remain the same and do not reflect input from experienced staff. Staff work hard, but the charity does not offer appraisals that recognise this. Only basic 1% salary increase in April, Unlocking Potential does not offer appraisals, promotions or any raises based on individual merit and hard work.

review_title: A growing, committed and passionate charity
pros:
Genuinely passionate about supporting the community, offering a range of interventions to suit different needs. 
Recently some management restructuring has meant more room for staff to grow and develop in a field where there aren't always such opportunities. 
A committed, thoughtful team that does its best to listen to staff and to take ideas and suggestions on board.
cons:
In the past there weren't many CPD opportunities but this is rapidly changing and now staff is offered more training days. This process has been done with the participation of staff who were asked to let management know which areas they are in most need of support.
Much thought is given to how to promote diversity and inclusivity in the charity.

review_title: Growing charity who care for their employees
pros: My colleagues are incredibly supportive. The leadership team are personable, kind and caring. We are encouraged to explore our professional interests and supported to complete CPD. The charity has a diverse range of psychotherapists/counsellors who are trained in many different modalities which adds depth to the Schools Programme and to the services we offer. As a Manager there are always new opportunities to develop/improve the operational aspects of the charity, as well as great opportunities to set up new provisions.
cons: There are very few cons, the charity excels above and beyond in many areas and it is almost impossible to find flaws, however if I had to name one area for development it would be the overall growth strategy.

review_title: A growing charity, talented and thoughtful colleagues
pros: UP have grown as a charity in recent years, this is opening up new opportunities for staff development. The staff are hugely talented , thoughtful and committed to the children and families; they are a brilliant and warm team to work with.
cons: There has been a lot of leadership change in recent years and previously there was little scope to develop. However this change settled, more management roles have been created, there is a larger team overall and this is allowing for growth and staff development.

pros: UP is a great charity to work for. At UP you'll be working with supportive colleagues who are committed to providing excellent therapeutic interventions to some of the most vulnerable children and young people across London. UP is committed to staff wellbeing understanding how vital this is in ensuring excellent services for the children and young people it supports.
cons: No cons, have found UP to be an excellent charity to work for
Unpleasant senior management team. Lack of diversity among senior management & trustee team considering they are dealing with different minority backgrounds.

pros:
The opportunity to work with marginalised children and help them succeed.
One or two lovely people.
cons:
Unpleasant staff members, bullying culture with no concern for mental health nor wellbeing.
Poor location. Children kicking equipment into neighbours house due to lack of space.

Staff have been attacked by dogs upon entering the building. 

Particular staff members making false allegations against other staff. Focus not on the children, moreso on power and being in control. Lack of structure and boundaries. Gossiping, backbiting and bullying.

Staff who actually care about the children have been removed unfairly as a result of false allegations and spiteful behaviour. 


A lot of drama and picking on people. This is then picked up on by the children and its unacceptable. 
The most horrible place I've ever worked in.

pros: Have seen many colleagues progress in the charity. Our School based mental health service is growing , which is great given the need. The service is continually developing. Passionate and committed CEO and managers.

Some staff are clearly passionate, committed and dedicated to their work 

Working with young children and being able to see the positive impact the charity has to them.
cons:
Extremely bad management and structure across the organisation. 

No cohesion of staff amongst programmes.

Majority of SMT are particularly cut-throat and self-motivated. 

Lack of ethnic diversity across the organisation (extremely disappointing when the majority of the charities beneficiaries come from BAME background).

CEO is prone to providing false information in all aspects of the charity. 

Not much opportunity to progress within the organisation.

pros: Great team of knowledgable therapists. Thoughtful approach.
cons: A lot of work for little pay. No career advancement opportunities.
